IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
INCIDENT: DUI/DWI/ACRS

SUSPECT: Matthew Grason Tull
DOB: 2/15/1972
ADDRESS: 11435 Longwoods Rd. Easton, MD 21601
PRIORS: Repeat offender

SCENE PROCESSING: BWC and In car camera operational.

NARRATIVE:

On August 6, 2023 at approximately 1454 hours, I, TFC. S. Glover #6819, was dispatched to the area of Longwoods Road and Wye Heights Road for the report of a single vehicle collision into a pole.  I arrived on scene at approximately 1505 hours and observed a green Jeep Wrangler bearing Maryland registration 6FH9420 that had struck a pole.  The Jeep was registered to Mr. Matthew Grason Tull (2/15/1972) W/M who lived just down the road at 11435 Longwoods Roadd Easton, MD 21601.  Mr. Tull was not on scene upon my arrival.  I made contact with Mr. Tull at his residence and asked him what had happened to his vehicle.  Mr. Tull advised me that he had left to go to the store and had crashed into the pole.  Mr. Tull stated that he was intending on calling a tow truck for his vehicle.  Mr. Tull also advised me that he had been drinking before he started driving and that he had nothing to drink after his collision.  Mr. Tull had a small cut to his right arm.  I offered to Mr. Tull to call EMS to have him treated, which he refused.  I provided basic medical care and placed a gauze bandage on his arm for him.  I could smell the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from Mr. Tull's breath and person.  I observed that his eyes were bloodshot and glassy.  Mr. Tull was severely slurring his speech and kept repeating sentences that he had already told me.  I transported Mr. Tull back to the location of the collision to conduct field sobriety testing, as his driveway was slanted and filled with gravel.  Mr. Tull agreed to take all field sobriety tests.

I asked Mr. Tull if he was currently on any prescription medications.  Mr. Tull advised that he was on numerous prescription medications, but he couldn't recall what all of them were.  Mr. Tull advised that the medications were all for a heart attack that he had suffered previously.  Mr. Tull did state that the medications were "blood thinners" and "baby aspirin" and "everything related to a heart attack."  Mr. Tull advised that he was not injured and besides the heart attack, was not under the care of a physician for anything additional.  Mr. Tull advised that he wears glasses normally, but did not have glasses or contacts in at the time.  Mr. Tull advised again that he had drank about "three beers" prior to leaving for the store.  Mr. Tull stated that they were approximately 10 ounce beers.

HGN: 6/6 VGN Present

I explained the test to Mr. Tull who stated that he understood.   I observed that Mr. Tull had equal pupil sized and was able to track the stimulus equally.  Mr. Tull exhibited lack of smooth pursuit, distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation, and nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes.  Mr. Tull did not perform this test to my satisfaction as he exhibited 6/6 clues.  Mr. Tull also exhibited Vertical Gaze Nystagmus, which indicates a high level of alcohol concentration for that individual.

Walk and Turn Test: 4/8

I explained and demonstrated the test to Mr. Tull, who stated that he understood.  Mr. Tull was placed in the starting position where he remained as I explained the test.  Mr. Tull began when he was advised.  Mr. Tull missed heel to toe on step 3, stepped offline on step 4, missed heel to toe again on step 5, and missed heel to toe again on step 9.  After step 9, Mr. Tull stopped walking and waited prior to completing a turn.  Mr. Tull was then instructed to complete a turn, which he did not complete as instructed, by not leaving his lead foot planted.  After completing the turn, Mr. Tull again waited prior to walking.  After being reminded to complete 9 more steps, Mr. Tull began his return 9 steps.  Mr. Tull did not exhibit any clues on the return 9 steps.  Mr. Tull did not complete this test to my satisfaction as he exhibited 4/8 clues on this test.

-Missed heel to toe
-Stepped offline 
-Stops walking
-Improper turn

One Leg Stand: 2/4

I explained and demonstrated the test to Mr. Tull, which he stated that he understood.  Mr. Tull began to balance picking up his left foot.  Mr. Tull then began to hop and put his foot back down.  Mr. Tull tried again and put his foot back down and advised me that he "can't balance like that."  Mr. Tull tried several more times, prior to saying he couldn't continue the test.  Mr. Tull did not complete this test to my satisfaction as he exhibited 2/4 clues on this test.

-Puts foot down
-Hops

Preliminary Breath Test: 0.22

I explained the test to Mr. Tull and advised that there were no penalties for not taking the test.  Mr. Tull agreed to submit to the preliminary breath test and provided a sample of 0.22.

Mr. Tull was placed under arrest at approximately 1534 hours.  Prior to leaving the scene, Mr. Tull was provided a copy of the DR-15 which was played via my in car computer using the MVA audio version on the MVA website.  Mr. Tull advised that he would agree to take a breath test back at the barrack at approximately 1544 hours.  Mr. Tull was transported back to the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack for the breath test.  The test was conducted by Sgt. Goldman #5470.  Mr. Tull submitted to the test at approximately 1623 hours. Tull's breath specimen was found to contain an alcohol concentration of .20 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath.  Mr. Tull was charged with the appropriate citations and issued all appropriate paperwork.  Additionally, Mr. Tull had an alcohol restriction on his license at the time of this incident.

Mr. Tull was ultimately released to a sober driver.

I am a certified police officer in the state of Maryland.  I have been a police officer for approximately 6 years.  I have made numerous arrests for suspicion of driving under the influence in my career.  I am certified in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE).   I have over 40 hours of training through the Maryland State Police Academy in the detection and recognition of impaired drivers, including testing on live subjects.  I was able to determine Mr. Tull to be impaired through my training, knowledge, and experience.

All events occurred in Talbot County, Maryland.
